text: [Music]
What's going on everybody? Mortem here.
This time bringing you my review after
100% for the first Berserker Kazan. A
soulslike or perhaps more aptly a
neolike that relatively recently
released. And discounting a few minor
quibbles, I mostly had a really great
time with it. The combat is awesome and
I really think that it actually
reignited some feelings for the genre
that I haven't gotten in quite some
time. Before we get into all that, I
review games after 100% all the time to
set me apart from other reviewers on the
platform. And while that doesn't include
the achievements and also includes a lot
more than that, there's a link below
covering everything I go over and my
Steam profile is public and linked below
as well. What's more though, I did
receive a review key for this, but it
was right as the early access period for
the pre-orders started. So, I did
technically have it a little bit early
with the game itself having released
back on March 27th. So, like a week or
so past. And then lastly, a tiny bit of
a spoiler warning. Not so much for what
I'm going to say, but rather footage you
might see in the background. Ultimately,
this is a game where the bosses are like
these big events. And I know for some
people playing a Souls like that's a
pretty big deal. And I'm going to be
showing a lot of what are ultimately
only like 12 bosses or at least sort of
main bosses if you will. So, you may
just want to listen to this one instead.
But story-wise, I'm not really going to
cover too much outside of some mentions
of the different potential endings. But
otherwise, it is a pretty
straightforward, albeit somewhat
difficult 100% in terms of the fights
and things you have to master all on
your own without using the helper
features and the like. In fact, by far
and a way the most difficult part of
this entire sort of review process was
the last boss, which literally took me
about 6 hours to do solo on the regular
mode without summoning in any help so I
could get all of the achievements in a
single go. And then afterwards, I, you
know, went back and checked out some of
the easier stuff as well. But despite
spending 6 hours on that boss and a lot
of the other bosses actually taking me
some time as well, not a single one of
them felt unfair. but rather it felt
like each one of them had something it
had to teach me and I just wasn't going
to move on until I figured it out. Very
rarely did this game ever make me feel
like something it was doing wasn't uh
fair or you know cheap in some way. And
while that did come up with the
occasional technical problem which we're
about to discuss, by far and away this
game felt just like a really challenging
love letter to the genre as a whole,
which is why I really enjoyed it. Now,
while the, you know, sort of hardest way
to play the game is in fact quite
difficult through various summons you
can pull into battle on top of being
able to reduce the difficulty down to
easy, which is permanent for a
playthrough by the way, you do have some
options if that's not your thing. But
speaking about the technical state of
this one, while I would say this title
was mostly fine on that regard, there
were some things that were definitely of
note. The game did crash on me a couple
times across about 60 hours. Nothing too
crazy, but slightly annoying to be sure.
With this game saving pretty much all
the time, as most Souls legs do, you
don't really lose any progress when that
happens. But a much more substantial
thing that I occasionally ran into,
which luckily seemed pretty rare, was
that sometimes when bosses were doing
their big sort of windup attacks, like
the uh sort of animation would just
disappear. So if they were shooting a
beam at you, which in often cases has
like a light trigger at the end where
you need to dodge or parry at that
point, sometimes you just wouldn't see
any of that and you could still get hit
by the attack though, which is obviously
not a good time. Again, seemed
relatively rare, but it happened enough
times to be like, okay, this is clearly
an issue. Now, what I did think was
interesting is that even when that did
happen in a fight, it did not like
consistently happen. and it would
usually just be like one or two attacks
and then even if they use that same
attack later, it wouldn't do that, which
was an odd one for sure, but otherwise I
didn't have any issues. Next up, let's
talk about difficulty and new game plus.
So, this game does have an easy or
normal mode alongside a new game plus
available after you beat the game, which
continues gear progression and things
like that, as with plenty of other Souls
likes really. Now, the game does have a
sort of fun way of introducing the
difficulty to you, though. It just
starts you on normal from what I
understand. But if you die three times
in the opening level or you finish that
opening level without dying three times,
you'll then be presented with the
difficulty option. Again, choosing easy
mode is permanent. You cannot switch it
back when I initially saw this choice. I
obviously just chose normal for the
achievements and stuff, but I did not
realize at that time that the choice
when you do that is a permanent thing.
So, you know, be sure that's what you
want to do before you do it. But easy
mode alongside being able to summon
spirits of advocacy for boss fights is
really how you're going to be able to
mitigate how challenging this game can
be otherwise. And to be fair, it is
quite challenging. As somebody who plays
a fair few Souls Legs, this was the most
trouble I've had with one in a while.
Though to be fair, I did go with the
hardest option right away to get all
that stuff knocked out. Speaking about
easy mode though, basically what this
does is make Kazan hit harder and take
less damage, which seems pretty obvious,
but the way it does that is through a
few different means, obviously, by just
straight up increasing your damage
numbers and the like, but you'll take
even less damage by the game beefing up
your resistances and things like that.
Your stamina also recovers faster. Your
weight limit is increased. So,
basically, through all of those
different means, you're just able to do
more more easily, which is going to make
the game easier by default. Of course,
some of these bosses are challenging
enough that I still think some people,
especially if you're not familiar with
the genre, might struggle a little bit,
but there are some ways to make that
more accessible. The other one being the
spirits of advocacy. Basically, these
are guys you can summon to help you with
your various boss fights. They just act
as another character to distract the
boss, of course, a common enough thing
in these games these days. They do
actually have a little separate uh side
progression. In order to summon these
spirits, you have to first defeat
remnants of adversity, which are just
boss fights with other characters that
you can summon in that kind of have
similar move sets to yours. And when you
defeat them, you get a currency. That
currency is used to summon those spirits
of advocacy, but also you can spend more
of it to upgrade them at an NPC. Next up
though, let's talk the story setup and
my thoughts on it. So, the first
Berserker, Kazan, is set in the Dungeon
Fighter Online universe, which I'm not
particularly familiar with myself. But
in this case, it tells the origin story
of a character known as Kazan, the first
Berserker, if you would believe it. In
particular, though, General Kazan and
his friend Osma defeated a Berserk
dragon known as Hismar that was
threatening the Empire, only to turn
around and then be betrayed and branded
a traitor. Kazan is being sent to his
death. But thanks to the intervention of
what is known as a blade phantom, who
possesses Kazan, he manages to free
himself and start carving a bloody path
of vengeance across the empire. The
Blade Phantom is a servant of Keron, the
Lord of the Underworld, and is in fact
an amalgamation of different spirits
using Kazan in order to enact Keron's
will, which in this case is to find out
what the problem is out in the world
that is draining souls or Lacma from the
netherworld, which seems to line up well
enough for Kazan's path of revenge.
Along the way, you can complete a few
different tasks that lead to one of the
game's three endings. Now, I will say
most of these endings are very similar.
There is a true ending that there is a
specific achievement for, and the true
ending does require a much harder final
boss fight, which is one of the reasons
I was stuck on it for so long. But
essentially, it just comes down to doing
all of the game's bonus missions,
collecting a bunch of logs and journals
you can find to give you more
information, which itself has an
achievement attached to it, which is an
easy way to know that you've met the
requirement, and then finally, a
dialogue choice you pick right at the
end of the game. Again though, none of
these are like wildly different from one
another. You just get a little bit of
extra information from the true ending,
which kind of pushes the overall
narrative forward. And while I would
argue that none of them are really good,
of the three, that one is a bit more uh
I guess hopeful might be the word. So
overall, the narrative is decent. I
wouldn't really say it's mind-blowing or
anything. Pretty standard Tale of
Revenge, but it certainly has its
moments. Now, moving on to progression
systems. Some of this is very standard
Soulslike stuff. Other parts of it are a
little more specific to this game. First
up, we have our levels. As we kill
enemies, we of course obtain our
currency/experience from them. In this
case, lacrima, which are basically just
souls. We then spend this lacrima to
level up one of our various stats. These
stats are connected to a bunch of
derivative stats, and our weapons scale
off a few different ones. Diminishing
returns occurs for everything but weapon
damage, as per the usual. Now, while we
fight enemies and perform in combat with
certain weapon types and everything,
basically do things uh the correct way,
you earn experience towards your skill
points. You spend your skill points on
either sort of general things that your
character can learn, or on more specific
abilities for each individual weapon
type, dual wielding, great swords, or
spears. All of these can be effective.
Personally, I prefer dual wield by far,
but if you're looking for optimal, it
does kind of feel like spear might be
the way to go there. We then of course
have our gear. So gear is one of the
areas of this game that it's very
similar to Neo. You get all sorts of
gear pieces with various rarity tiers.
As you increase in level, the higher
tiers become more common. And each of
these bits of gear has various affixes
and modifiers it can do to your various
stats. What's more, some of this stuff
is attached to a set bonus. A little
later into the game, you can increase
the level of the items you find, which
is a handy way of increasing, say, a set
that you have put together that you want
to keep using. And this is going to, of
course, keep the stats updated for you
as well. And then once you unlock the
blacksmith, you can actually deliver
items to him, which will allow you to
craft specific sets of gear if you have
the resources to do so, which is another
way to make sure you have the set bonus
that you want to play around with.
Personally, I wound up settling on the
executioner set because it just worked
for my play style, but there's a whole
host of different stuff, including
different uh weights of armor, which
will affect things like your ability to,
of course, dodge and whatnot. And that
on top of also getting the ability to
change out the various modifiers on an
individual piece of gear, means you can,
if you are dedicated, sort of set up a
perfect set of gear for yourself, which
will almost certainly make the game a
little easier. What's more, though, we
also have our phantoms. As I mentioned
earlier, the Blade Phantom is not one
single entity, but rather an
amalgamation of phantoms, each
previously a person of some marshall
renown. You can sort of equip one of
these phantoms to yourself and even find
items to awaken specific abilities as
well. These are going to modify things
like your stamina recovery, your ranged
weapon, or your javelin throw, basically
your health recovery, just various
things like that. and then the items
that boost them up alongside having it
just equipped will increase its level
making those effects more pronounced.
There's also Kazan's memories. Every
time you sort of fully complete a
mission, that is to say, get all the
collectibles, beat the boss, etc.,
you'll earn uh points in the Kazan's
memory, which you can access from any
individual checkpoint or sort of sword
that's sticking out of the ground. And
you can spend this currency you get from
completing these missions fully on
upgrades to things like your damage,
your damage multiplier, or your stamina
damage to enemies, which is very useful.
Of course, there are also soul stones.
You'll find soul stones are scattered
around levels as you move through them.
And when you break those soul stones,
they get added to your currency for
that. And then once you meet Defrona,
the NPC that deals with them, you can
use that soul stone energy you've
collected to give yourself bonuses to
either your experienced gained or your
netherworld energy, which will increase
the amount you heal yourself with your
healing item that recharges upon rest.
Now, occasionally when you unleash these
soul stones, it also increases your max
spirit, which is your ability to unleash
your skills. And when you put all that
together, there really is just a sort of
surprising amount of progression here
across a whole variety of levels, which
means every time you move through a
level, it really does feel like you're
getting a lot done. But I will say it is
very possible to play through this way
in a game that is extremely linear
because it is missionbased. Which brings
us to the gameplay and world. The first
Berserker Kazan is in fact a
missionbased game. Those missions
basically coming down to main versus
side missions. Each of those missions
typically ends with a boss encounter of
some sort. But as you move through the
level, it is extremely similar to Neo.
We access these missions, however, from
what becomes our sort of player hub
known as the crevice in the Nether World
and the mortal realm. It's where we're
going to interact with a lot of NPCs, do
our upgrades, etc. From the Netherworld
side of the crevice, though, we can
interact with these stones that then
teleport us into the various missions of
our choosing. In those missions, it's
pretty standard Soulslike stuff. You've
got your checkpoints, which act as your
place to rest, which will heal you,
recharge your healing items, which is
your opportunity to allow you to level
up the usual stuff. While this will
respawn enemies, of course, things like
your checkpoints you've unlocked, etc.
to make traversal through that mission
easier, stay up to date, and some things
like elite enemies don't respawn after
you kill them. Probably worth a mention
in here somewhere that we cannot jump. I
don't know why this feels like a game
you should really be able to jump in,
but probably something to do with some
of the platforming sections. But
unfortunately, you cannot. But outside
of just fighting everything here, but
we're going to basically do is look for
those collectibles I mentioned, the soul
stones, these jarlings you can find,
because the more of those you find, they
get sent back to an NPC that deals with
them, which can then sell you things
like lanterns or, you know, specific jar
helmets, which is kind of funny. And
things like the lanterns have specific
effects on gameplay because things like
say elucory doors or walls I suppose I
should say which then lead to secrets
and things like that can be revealed by
those lanterns. Undead enemies as an
example will try to rise up from the
grave which then requires you to hit
their dead body an extra time once that
starts. But you can get a lantern to
negate that effect if you have it turned
on as an example. And then of course
we're going to meet various NPCs along
the way. That Jarwin of course being a
prime example. And interacting with them
and getting their bonus missions as a
result is going to give you some extra
context to the story as what they've got
going on is the bulk of a lot of the
bonus missions you'll come up with. But
ultimately a Souls Like is primarily
about combat. So let's get on to the
bulk of this which is the combat itself.
Lucky for us it's by far and away the
best part of this game. It genuinely
feels great and I enjoyed playing around
with it. Now, there are ultimately those
three types of weapons I've already
mentioned. Spears, dual wielding, or
great swords. Each of them has different
stats. It scales off of different
abilities and skills to use. And I think
they do a good job of each having a
pretty distinct play style while still
ultimately having the same core. In
order to evade enemies, you can dodge,
parry, or block. Blocking at the exact
right moment. Performs a brink guard,
which is in effect a parry, and then
dodging at the last second as well is
your brink dodge, which is your perfect
dodge. And each of those typically has
extra effects. Like for instance,
perfect parries won't actually damage
your stamina instead of, you know,
taking stamina away from you with a
normal block. We've got the other
standard stuff like our healing items
that we can find extra charges for,
which of course allows us to heal.
That's actually pretty limited in the
beginning portions of the game. It takes
a while to get a decent amount of
charges to your healing. As you run
enemies out of stamina or their sort of
netherworld energy for more monster type
enemies, we can perform brutal attacks
with some upgrades. You can perform
these brutal attacks simply by dropping
down to enemies or in other situations.
And those brutal attacks obviously deal
major damage and in some cases are
pretty clutch in destroying certain
enemy types. You also about halfway or
so through the game get access to the
phantom form. This takes a while to
actually get, but I would say is another
thing they kind of take from Neo
actually. So the phantom form is your
ability to of course take on the form of
the phantom that is following you
around. This effectively gives you a
second health bar for a limited time,
and it's a great way to tank some
tougher attacks from enemies you might
be having trouble with. You can lean
fully into this phantom form, allowing
you to use it more often, and it can
even save you from death for a lot of
skill points, alongside upgrading its
duration and damage. And it is most
effective, like with most things in this
game, if you start to understand the
individual enemy types you come up
against. For instance, the undead try to
rise up from their initial death as I've
already mentioned. And for the later
types of undead in the game, which are
actually quite strong, that's a problem.
So that lantern you get as an example
that can prevent that is super helpful.
In fact, there is one specific type of
undead enemy that will uh be invisible
when you first come up against them, but
you can see their footsteps. And there
is a separate lantern that will actually
sort of stun those guys when you first
run into them, which will prevent them
from hitting you with a sneak attack.
Now, more human type enemies typically
have a stamina bar of some description.
If you run that stamina bar down, which
does regenerate the way yours does, you
can hit them with a brutal attack once
you've exhausted them. Monster type
enemies typically have a sort of like
energy gauge where they don't have a
stamina restriction the way that other
enemies do, but rather they simply have
that gauge that once you hit them
enough, it slowly goes down, but it
doesn't regenerate as part of that
process. And so, it's a little easier
with consistency to get it through. But
then we also have elite enemies which
work a little differently. They can
often go into a frenzy mode which is a
very increased attack pattern and they
also have extra effects. Now elite
enemies when destroyed do not come back
once you've killed them on a mission.
They stay dead until you run that
mission again by you know leaving and
coming back or whatever. Now the elites
primarily and like one or two of the
bosses did have a mechanic that got old
pretty quick which was that some of them
can uh get life back from hitting you. A
life steal mechanic. Now, personally,
I'm fine with enemies that do that, uh,
you know, once or twice as just
something to throw you off a little bit,
sure, but they get a little carried away
with that mechanic towards the end of
the game. A significant amount of the
elite enemies use it. A couple of bosses
will use it. Luckily, they are mostly
side bosses, but still, it just gets
old. I honestly think they overused that
mechanic. It's very annoying. But let's
get on to the bulk of combat. Let's talk
a little bit about the bosses in
particular because I think they are
fantastically well done for the main
missions. Now, a sort of catch 22 to
that is that this game has a relatively
limited amount of missions to do. And
unfortunately, a lot of the bosses for
side missions are just a rehash of the
main mission bosses. It'll be
effectively the same fight with maybe
some minor tweaks with an enemy that has
a slightly different name, which I I
didn't love to be honest. I get that
that's common enough in these types of
games, but I didn't love it. Especially
seeing how some side missions actually
take a different approach with giving
you like combinations of multiple
enemies that have, you know, amped up
stats as a result. And those typically
were at least a little more interesting
than just again rehashes of the main
bosses. So, I think that boss reuse gets
a little old, but that's hardly a
problem unique to this game
specifically, which is probably the same
to be said of the camera sometimes. a
very common action game problem to have
where sometimes the camera is not always
agreeable. But as we start talking about
bosses, I want to mention one of my
favorite little quality of life changes
that this game gives you. You see, when
you attempt a boss, you are actually
earning experience the more you damage
that boss. It gives it to you after that
boss is uh you know either kills you or
you kill it or whatever as normal. But
say you try a boss, you ultimately get
defeated. When you resurrect at the last
uh checkpoint you used as normal, you
actually gain experience for having just
fought that boss. And what's more, the
experience you just dropped from dying
on that boss, as the risk of losing your
experience because of a terrorizing run
back to try to claim it from where you
died last is a hallmark of the genre as
well. In this case, that experience is
dropped outside of the boss arena. So,
you can through this method basically
earn experience from just attempting a
boss, which is going to allow you to
level up and get stronger as you make
repeated attempts, which I really think
is a great way to encourage people to
continually try bosses and overcome that
challenge. I actually think it's a
really ingenious solution to a problem
in the sense that it encourages uh
people to do exactly what the genre is
supposed to be about, coming up against
a, you know, monster that's like, "Oh,
this is crazy hard. I don't know how I'm
going to do this." And then through
repeated attempts and memorization,
learning what that boss is about and
overcoming the challenge, that little
system is such just a wonderful way of
reinforcing that central theme that this
genre is about. But another thing that I
loved about all of the main bosses is
that there is not a single one I would
point to and be like that boss was, you
know, unfair in some way. I think all of
these bosses are exceptionally
welldesigned and every one of them kind
of taught me something about the game
and made me better at it as a result of
that. even if I was stuck on it for a
while. The most notable first roadblock
you're likely going to run into is
Viper. He's the first like serious boss
the game has. There's like three bosses
leading up to that guy that are not
nearly as difficult. But the thing about
Viper is that while he does have a two
health bar, fourphase, shockingly
difficult fight for so early on in the
game. He's also got a move set that is
extremely well telegraphed and easy
enough to learn after a few attempts.
And with the spirits of advocacy and the
easy mode there if you need it, this
boss ultimately serves as a bit of a
skill check for everything else you're
about to run into. Now, I want to talk
about a few other bosses that again just
kind of taught me something. So, I
thought that was interesting. So, the
boss after Viper is called Volbano, I
think his name is, like this giant goat
thing. And a little ways into his fight,
he starts lighting up one of his weapons
with fire damage. And the thing about
that is uh up to that point I was just
doing the perfect parries thing all the
time in order to avoid damage. But this
boss fight teaches you that elemental
damage on a weapon will actually pierce
through a perfect parry. You will of
course block the attack and it won't
like you know knock you back or
whatever, but the elemental damage from
that weapon hitting you still goes
through which can then increase the
status effect buildup leading to the
actual effect. And this boss fight
teaches you through, of course, attempts
to deal with that, which is either going
to come in the form of increasing your
resistance to it through potions or
gear, or you could also just dodge and
not get hit by an elementally charged
weapon to begin with. So, if you're
hitting those things, you won't have to
deal with the elemental buildup. And at
that point in the game, you don't have a
lot of healing charges. So, trying to
deal with that status effect is
paramount. And that's a boss fight I
walked away from having learned, okay, I
know how to deal with this specific
thing in this game. Now, moving forward
a little bit, there's another boss later
on called Elmagne. Elmagne is a boss
that very brutally teaches you not to
overextend because Elmagne does
something other bosses do not do. She
has a special attack specifically for
when you run out of stamina. Other
bosses won't do this. You know, if you
depending on when you do it, overreach
and just recover your stamina before
they attack you, you're good to go.
Elamine, on the other hand, has an
attack that only triggers when you run
out of stamina. So, overcoming that boss
fight was really just about learning uh
to pace yourself and not overreach
against this specific boss cuz she'll
punish you very hard for it. The sort of
final boss of the first part of the game
is a guy called Maluca. Maluca has a
brutal phase that I really learned that
it was mostly best to just survive
rather than try to do any damage during
or you know focus more on survival than
dealing damage while that happened
because he has a phase where he pulls
out a katana and just does like these
crazy almost kind of anime moves and
they're really hard to perfectly parry
because of how quick they are. But the
thing is he cycles out of that phase
every so often and pulls out his other
two swords. The swords are much easier
to deal with. So, what I found was that
rather than trying to perfect parry
everything he does while he has that
katana out, it was better to just, you
know, again, focus on surviving, maybe
get some hits in where I can, but play
it pretty safe and then once he pulls
his two swords back out, go ham again.
As those were much easier and more
telegraphed and thus more manageable.
And while that really is just a few
examples, I wanted to mention so many of
them just because again, I walked away
from almost every boss this game has
feeling accomplished and like I had
learned more about this game and become
better at it as a result. And I really
think that is such a highlight of the
first Berserker's content because yes, I
would say even for a Souls like this
game can be quite difficult. And I've
played plenty of Souls like before and
this is the first one in a long time to
sort of give me those feelings, which is
why I enjoyed the combat as much as I
did. And let's be honest, a huge part of
the combat itself is very similar to Neo
1 and 2. And if you like those games, I
think you'll probably enjoy this as
well. But all of that does bring us to
the Steam Deck section for this game.
So, the first Berserker Kazan is in fact
verified on the Steam Deck, and I can
certainly see why. It plays very well
there. It has controller support, of
course, cloud saves, the usual stuff you
want. And what's more, you can get a
really good frame rate, which is exactly
what you want in these more
actionoriented titles, even if you do
have to sacrifice, of course, some
visual quality for that. But otherwise,
yeah, you should absolutely be able to
play this on the Steam Deck pretty well.
Which brings us to our positives and
negatives. and then we can move on with
our lives. So, on the positive side of
things, while I wouldn't say anything
about the first Berserker Kazan is truly
unique in the sense that I've seen
plenty of Souls liked that do almost
everything in this game, what it does is
execute on those things in an incredible
way. The combat is phenomenal. I really
enjoyed playing it because while I might
have been stuck on that final boss for 6
hours, I really did enjoy all of that,
which is saying something. And I think a
lot of that is helped along by the fact
that they have those really just
ingenious quality of life changes like
giving you experience for boss attempts
which allows you to level up as you make

think uh enemies having a life steal
mechanic in the endame just gets used
way too often. I think like plenty of

that issue with uh bosses occasionally
just, you know, having attacks kind of
disappear without being able to see what

most substantial issue by far. All of
which brings me to my conclusion. So,
The First Berserker Kazan is an
interesting game in the sense that what
